content.description: This is an odd one. 20 feet long with no pro. Best to lead the first pitch of "Regular Route" and swing over and set up a toprope. Don't bother slinging the spike, pretty useless.
content.protection: None, good spotter and pads, or toprope it.
content.location: As you descend the scree slope from the parking lot, the first anchor, quite low, with no pro below.

content.description: A route you can make harder, or easier, depending on how closely you stick to the bolts. Staying to the left of the bolts after the bulge, (the last half of the route), makes it harder, to the right, easier. Any way you choose, a really fun line.
content.location: The second line of bolts as you descend the scree hill, almost to the bottom. Shares the same anchors as "Bone Breaker".

content.description: A succession of slabby friction moves through a line of inverted steps, the crux is down low; if you stick clip the first bolt, this is a good place to break into the 11's. Don't discount above the first bolt, it stays slick and slabby to the top.
content.location: About halfway between Barney Rubble and where the upper roof/dihedral comes down to the ground, you'll find a slick looking start with a bolt about 12' off the ground. If it looks like an 11, you're there.

content.description: Short and Sweet. If it feels like it's harder than 10.a, just keep looking. Once you figure it out, yep, it's 10.a! The top is...thought provoking, the anchor looks a long way from that last bolt.
content.location: On the far right of the main wall there is a giant cave/hole 30' off the ground. To the right and down from this are the rightmost bolted lines, which share an anchor. The left hand one is "Wiring...".

climbs.name: Ursus Horribilis
climbs.fa: David Cook, Steve and Annette Edwards, 1993

content.description:
All pitches have bolt and chain anchors plus listed bolts

P1) - 5.7+, 4 bolts

First bolt quick simple scramble.  Don't confuse this with the first bolt of "3 Weenies...".

P2) - 5.7, 5 bolts  (loose flakes)

P3) - 5.9, 3 bolts

P4) - 5.6R, 1 bolt and pro to 2" (short).
content.protection: Good quality bolts, Pitches have anchors with chains
content.location: In the parking lot, the second bolted line in from the road. Can be difficult to spot the bolts. Look for the left facing dihedral of the "Regular Route"; right of this, 75' up, spot the chain anchor of "Ursus..". Line of 4 bolts directly beneath this. The tread marks on the rock are easy to spot.

content.description: 3 bolts, the first quite high, lead to the same anchors as "Between the Lines". Clipping the 3rd bolt is really the crux. More like 5.8 and PG-13, a good intro to 5.9.
content.location: Starts 15' to the right of "Barney Rubble', pretty close to "Between the Lines". First bolt is just a bit lower than the second bolt of "Between the Lines".

content.description: Slabby runout first pitch.  Second pitch dirty until the head wall then 30 ft of fun climbing.  Be careful rapping.  Rope can get stuck on sharp rocks and a sixty meter rope will require some down climbing.
content.protection: Bolts with chain.  Take a couple of trad draws to cinch tie 2 drill bits sticking out of the rock.
content.location: Far right hand side of the main wall.  Look for the left facing dihedral.

climbs.name: To Bosch or Not To Be

content.description: This is one of those lines which you have to force yourself to follow the bolts and not just walk up the much easier holds to the right, especially towards the end, where that anchor looks way up there, and you wonder why there are only 3 bolts.
content.location: The farthest right hand bolted route on the main wall. First bolt is 15' up.

climbs.name: Three Weenies Doing 5.12
climbs.fa: John Lesko, Brad Johnson, Ben Gohlke, 2001

content.description: Five bolts, 60M rope.  Large flake fell recently.  New first bolt.  Very runout first clip.
content.protection: Five bolts and anchors with chains.
content.location: Left of Ursus Horribillus. The second line in from the road, the first sport route.

content.description: Fun roof move. Well protected, good way to get familiar with roofs. Head up from the belay at the top of Barny Rubble through some easy loose rock (5.7). At the second bolt head left and clip a pin, then a bolt below the roof. Pull up and over, clip another bolt, and there is the anchor.
content.location: From the top of Barney Rubble, follow 2 bolts, head left of the 'nose' of the roof. Rap to the top of Barney Rubble.

content.description:
The large left facing dihedral marks the start of this climb.

P1) 5.5 no pro start leads to a 5.6 dihedral. There is a spot for a nut about half way up to the dihedral, hard to spot. Ends on a ledge above the broken rock.

P2) 5.5 Walk to climbers right side of ledge, clip bolt, head up mungy, confusing ledges, tending left and then finally right up an easy ramp to bolted belay. Careful not to drop mud on belayer!

Variation - 5.10a. Far right after clipping first bolt: Instead of heading back left, climb straight up past 3 more bolts directly to the belay. Clean rock, fun, 10.a/b.

P3) 5.7 Head up dirty rock climbers left to the base of the great dihedral. The bolt can be passed for less rope drag.
content.protection: Standard rack to 5". Bolts. Bolted anchors. Shoulder length slings.

content.description:
This is really one of the best, and often overlooked, lines on the main wall. 3 pitches of great exposure, wild moves (especially the 2nd pitch), and good protection make this a classic.

The crux is low and sandbagged, but the good news is it is well protected and gets easier quickly. The roof is really fun, one of those pitches you just want to run laps on. DO.

P1) 4 bolts. The crux is right at the first bolt; a small cam can be helpful between bolt 1 & 2. (10.b)

P2) 3 bolts. Head up the face past 2 bolts, clip the bolt which protects the airy but easier than it looks roof move, and up to the anchor. (5.9)

P3)  3 bolts A little dirty, especially after rain, but fun pitch. Bring tat for the anchor, it is often old, ratty, or gone. (5.7)
content.protection: 4 draws, bolted anchors. A small cam (.3-.5) on the first pitch can help between the first 2 bolts.
content.location: The line of bolts directly at the base of the roof/dihedral to the right of Finger Gag. It's possible to rap from P3 to the top of P1 with a 70m. The webbing on P3 is often missing/useless.

content.description: The name says it, but hey, at 12.a, a good trick. Be thoughtful between the second and third bolts, it's possible to land back on the belay ledge. Pretty well protected for the grade. The rating comes from the roof, but don't discount the slab below...
content.location: From the top of Together In the Sand, move the belay up and to the right to a bolted anchor. From here it is 3 bolts to the base of the roof and the business, then 2 bolts above to the anchor. It is also possible to move the belay from the top of Grizzly Terrace.

content.description: This is rally a free solo, best left alone or to those very comfortable with trad 5.7. Gear is to be found, thin, lousy, sparse, hard to spot, just below the mini-roofs, about 50' off the deck.
content.protection: Thin gear. .3-1". Hunt for it. Basically a free solo.
content.location: Look for a large scoop close to the road (5.5?). Head up this to a small corner topped by a couple of layers (mini roofs?). Rap from anchors.

climbs.name: Old Top Rope Route
climbs.fa: Randy Dewes, et. Al., 1983 may have been done much earlier in 70's, solo'ed

content.description: Great face climb.  Most often top roped need 60M rope.  Can be done on lead.  Pro micronuts/swedges through 1"
content.protection:
Top Rope. Anchors and chains.  Shares anchors with the Regular route.

If you choose to lead this; micro nuts, (screamers), small cams to .3, ball nuts, crash pads for the start.
content.location: Locate the black overhang in the far right of the parking lot directly below the first belay of 'Regular Route'.

climbs.name: JoBraJi Roof
climbs.fa: John Lesko, Brad Johnson, Jim Felder

content.description: This is really the second pitch of "You're no Warren Harding", but F.A. was years later and a different team, hence a different name. From the top of "...Harding", climb up, clip a bolt, get right under the roof, clip a bolt under the roof, and pull the crux 10.c move. Fun ,airy, and  a little dirty above.
content.location: From the top of "...Harding", straight up and over the roof. Can also be accessed from Deedeeleevee.

content.description: A 'clever' mashup of names and routes. The first two bolts of 'Bone Breaker', the last 3 of "You're no Warren Harding" make for a fun line. Climb through the first 2 on "Bone Breaker" then traverse right across an unprotected face to the 3rd bolt of "...Harding". Be careful on clipping the 3rd bolt, there is ground fall potential if you pull too much rope. Climb the smooth face to the left of Harding, ending at the same bolts.
content.location: Same start as "Bone Breaker".

content.description:
Another fun line to do laps and play on. Without a stick-clip it can be quite....heady, getting to the first bolt, 20' off the ground.

The second bolt is the 3rd bolt of "Woody Allen...", making the clip for many is the crux. Break out right again and clip the third bolt, then up to the anchor shared with "Woody Allen...".
content.location: Find the large (2"+) hole drilled into the face. Look up, first bolt 20' up.

content.description:
A clever name mashup by John Lesko, a little contrived, but fun nonetheless.

Climb the first 3 bolts of Finger Gag, when you get to the crux break right and clip the last 2 bolts of the first pitch of Out of Order.
content.location: Start on Finger Gag, finish on Out of Order. If you want to toprope other lines, it helps to have a cordelette to extend the anchor.

content.description:
A real challenge for the grade, difficult to read. Steep slab keeps you on your toes, and the crux is the namesake, when you get there, don't laugh, you might fall!

Look for the bulging pod, head up, and find your feet. Off to the races. The 4th bolt can be a challenge for the vertically challenged.
content.protection: 4 bolts, bolted anchor to the right of Grizzly Terrace.
content.location: Starts just to the right of Grizzly Terrace in an awkward bulgy pod; the first bolt is thankfully low.

content.description: Another fun roof move, definitely harder than Space Bucket. After the second bolt, head up to the right of the 'nose' of the roof. Fewer bolts than Space Bucket, a letter grade  (or 2) harder, make for an exciting ride. There is a slot for a small cam under the roof.
content.location: From the top of Barney Rubble, head straight up through 2 bolts, over the right side of the roof to the anchor. Lower off to top of Barney Rubble.

climbs.name: Deedeeleevee
climbs.fa: John Lesko, Deedee Vest, Ben Gohlke

content.description: A really great line through solid, clean rock. Well protected, although the first bolt is a little high for those under 5'10". A good intro to the style of the area.
content.location: As you get to the base of the scree hill from the parking lot, the route starts behind the giant boulder (which used to be part of the upper climbs). 70m rope to rap.

content.description: A thin 5.10 with entertaining moves which can be difficult to read. The climbing eases up as you get to the 3rd bolt, but don't relax. The name comes from the potential at the 3rd bolt. Use a stick clip for the start.
content.protection: 4 bolts, small cam (.3-.5) between 2nd and 3rd bolts.
content.location: As you descend the scree hill from the parking lot, look for a undercut w/2 close bolts. The third bolt is basically parallel with the anchor for "Zenith".

content.description: A bit of a squeeze job, hence the name. But there is enough there, and fun, to warrant it.
content.location: Just to the right of "Barney Rubble", first bolt is rather high, but easy to get to. Shares the anchor with "Together in The Sand".

content.description:
A one move wonder, of sorts, but fun at that. The line was put up after the massive rockfall which culminated in the giant boulder with bolts at the base of the climb.

It's possible to make this harder by keeping right in line with the bolts.
content.location: Look up to the midpoint mini-roof with an obvious bolt at it's base. The anchor is not visible from the ground.
